parameters.query:
-- Select document summaries or metadata for warm-up
-- Customize this query to retrieve the specific context you want to preload
SELECT 
    d.document_title AS title,
    string_agg(c.section_title || ': ' || LEFT(c.chunk_text, 500), '
') AS summary
FROM documents d
JOIN cag_document_registry c ON d.document_id = c.document_id
WHERE d.status = 'cached'
GROUP BY d.document_id, d.document_title

-- Retrieve context chunks based on semantic similarity
WITH user_query AS (
  SELECT '{{ $json.body.query }}'::text AS query_text
)
SELECT
  c.chunk_id,
  c.section_title,
  c.chunk_text,
  d.document_title,
  d.document_id
FROM cag_document_registry c
JOIN documents d ON c.document_id = d.document_id
WHERE d.status = 'cached'
  AND c.cag_status = 'cached'
  AND c.chunk_text ILIKE '%' || (SELECT query_text FROM user_query) || '%'
ORDER BY c.chunk_text ILIKE '%' || (SELECT query_text FROM user_query) || '%'
LIMIT 5;

parameters.content:
## CAG Retrieval from Local LLM . KV Cache management script separate
**Double click** to edit me. [Guide](https://docs.n8n.io/workflows/sticky-notes/)

## Feeding Whole Prompt at Querry
**Double click** to edit me. [Guide](https://docs.n8n.io/workflows/sticky-notes/)

## Configuration Instructions for Retrieval Workflow
1. Environment Variable Configuration
The workflow references $env.LLAMACPP_SERVER_URL which needs to be set in n8n:

In n8n, go to Settings (gear icon) â†’ Variables
Add a new variable:

Name: LLAMACPP_SERVER_URL
Value: http://cag-bridge:8000 (if using Docker setup) or http://localhost:8000 (if running locally)


Save your changes

2. HTTP Request Node Configuration
The "Query CAG Model" node needs to be configured correctly:

Select the "Query CAG Model" node
Verify the URL is set to {{ $env.LLAMACPP_SERVER_URL }}/query (or update it if needed)
Ensure the Content-Type header is set to application/json
Verify the body parameters contain:

query: ={{ $json.query }}
maxTokens: ={{ $json.maxTokens || 1024 }}
temperature: ={{ $json.temperature || 0.7 }}



3. Master KV Cache Creation
Before using the retrieval workflow, ensure a master KV cache exists:

Run the KV Cache Management workflow with the setAsMaster option set to true
Check that the master KV cache was created at the configured path (default: /data/kv_caches/master_cache.bin)
Note: The CAG Bridge assumes this master cache exists for all queries

4. Testing the Workflow

Create a test execution with input parameters:
jsonCopier{
  "query": "What are the key features of this system?",
  "maxTokens": 1024,
  "temperature": 0.7
}

Execute the workflow and verify the response is properly formatted

5. Endpoint Usage
When integrating with other applications, use:
CopierPOST http://localhost:5678/webhook/cag/query
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "query": "Your question about the document content",
  "maxTokens": 1024,
  "temperature": 0.7
}
Additional Recommendations

Error Handling: Consider adding error handling nodes to handle cases where the CAG Bridge is unavailable or the KV cache doesn't exist
Logging: Add a node to log queries and responses for monitoring and debugging
Caching: Consider implementing response caching for frequent queries to reduce load on the model

## Work in Progess

Additional Methods for Managing "Memory"

## Data Memory Management for Large Language Models: Project Overview
What This Project Is About
This project develops a sophisticated system for enhancing how large language models (LLMs) work with documents using a technique called Context-Augmented Generation (CAG). Unlike traditional approaches that slice documents into tiny chunks, this system leverages large context window models (128K tokens) to process entire documents and store their "memory state" for quick recall later.
Think of it like this: instead of giving an LLM random snippets of a book each time it's asked a question, this system lets the model "read the whole book once" and remember everything, making future questions much faster and more accurate.
Main Scenarios & Concepts
1. Context-Augmented Generation (KV Cache Management)
What it is: The core innovation of this project - using "memory snapshots" (KV caches) of documents that models can instantly access.
How it works:

Documents are processed once by large context models
The model's internal state (its "thoughts" about the document) is saved as a KV cache
Future queries use this pre-computed knowledge without re-reading the document

Key components: Document processing workflow, CAG Bridge, KV cache storage
2. Document Optimization
What it is: An intelligent preprocessing step that prepares documents for efficient storage.
How it works:

Uses Claude to clean up documents - removing redundancies and repetition
Preserves the meaning and structure while optimizing token usage
Makes documents more efficient for storage in the model's context window

Key components: Document optimization workflow, Claude API integration
3. Model Warm-up
What it is: A technique to "prime" the model with relevant knowledge before queries.
How it works:

Periodically feeds document summaries to the model
Keeps important information in the model's "working memory"
Improves response speed and quality for frequent topics

Key components: Scheduled triggers, document summary generation
4. Knowledge-Augmented Generation (KAG)
What it is: An extension that combines document knowledge with structured facts.
How it works:

Queries structured knowledge sources alongside documents
Blends factual information with contextual understanding
Provides more comprehensive and accurate responses

Key components: Knowledge graph integration, fact formatting
5. System Maintenance
What it is: Automated housekeeping to keep the system running efficiently.
How it works:

Cleans up temporary files and unused caches
Monitors system health and usage patterns
Maintains performance as document collections grow

Key components: Maintenance workflow, database monitoring
6. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)
What it is: The popular approach of retrieving relevant chunks from a vector database to augment LLM responses.
How it fits in this design:
While CAG is the primary focus of this project, RAG is intentionally designed as a complementary approach that can be called by the intelligent agent. The design intent allows for flexibility in how questions are answered:
How it works in this system:

The agent can evaluate each user query and decide the best approach
For some questions, the agent might call the CAG system for deep document knowledge
For others, it might call a RAG system for broader but shallower knowledge
The agent can even combine outputs from both systems for comprehensive answers

Why not the main focus: The project doesn't emphasize RAG implementation because there are already many excellent templates and implementations available. Instead, it focuses on the more innovative CAG approach while ensuring RAG compatibility.
